newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Plains fed cattle market inactive - feedlots.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Plains fed cattle market inactive - feedlots.

text.p: U.S. Plains feedlot cattle markets near midday Tuesday remained inactive, as packer buyers and cattle owners continued a standoff, feedlot sources said.
Packer bids ranged from $65.00 to $66.00 per cwt and were passed by owners pricing cattle at $69.00 to $70.00.
Prices this week, once sales occur, were seen steady to $1 higher, compared with last week's top at $68.00, sources said.
Fed cattle prices were expected to be supported amid talk that packers were running low on live cattle inventories and would need to replenish stocks by Wednesday or Thursday.
But sources said price strength could be limited by the fact some cattle left unsold last week were carried over to this week's showlists.
Gains in feedlot cattle prices this week also could be pared if beef prices continue working lower, they said.
Beef prices at midday were quoted down $1.05 to $2.04 per cwt on 273 fabricated beef loads sold, USDA said.
The price of heavier-weight choice beef was quoted down $1.05 at $104.92 -- down $2.87 from last Tuesday's close, USDA statistics showed.
